Module 4.2

Regression Tables and Coefficient Plots

Prework
  • Install peacesciencer and familiarize yourself with the documentation, install.packages("peacesciencer")

Use {peacesciencer}, teach broom, regression table package of some sort and coeffplots.

library(peacesciencer)
library(dplyr)

conflict_df <- create_stateyears(system = 'gw') |>
  filter(year %in% c(1949:2019)) |>
  add_ucdp_acd(type=c("intrastate"), only_wars = FALSE) |>
  add_democracy() |>
  add_creg_fractionalization() |>
  add_sdp_gdp() |>
  add_rugged_terrain()

glimpse(conflict_df)
Rows: 10,268
Columns: 20

library(broom)

conflict_model <- glm(ucdponset ~ ethfrac + relfrac + v2x_polyarchy + 
                        rugged + wbgdppc2011est + wbpopest,
                  data=subset(conflict_df),
                  family = binomial(link="logit"))

#tidy(conflict_model)

conflict_model |>
  tidy() |>
  mutate_if(is.numeric, round, 5)
# A tibble: 7 × 5

When a coefficient plot is better

A table is not as compelling for one model.

modelsummary(conflict_model, 
             stars = TRUE,  
             gof_map = c("nobs"),
             coef_map = coef_map,
             title = caption, 
             notes = reference)
Table 1: Predictors of Conflict Onset
 (1)
Ethnic Frac 0.679+
(0.366)
Religions Frac −0.392
(0.403)
Polyarchy −1.192**
(0.462)
Terrain −0.008
(0.077)
Per capita GDP −0.364***
(0.106)
Population 0.303***
(0.065)
Intercept −5.733***
(1.323)
Num.Obs. 8082
+ p < 0.1, * p < 0.05, ** p < 0.01, *** p < 0.001
See appendix for data sources.

Better to do a coefficient plot. Have to call ggplot2 for customization.

library(ggplot2)


modelplot(conflict_model, 
          coef_map = rev(coef_map), # rev() reverses list order
          coef_omit = "Intercept", 
          color = "blue") +
  # insert a red 0 line so it is easier to tell var significance
  geom_vline(xintercept = 0, color = "red", linetype = "dashed", linewidth = .75) +
  labs(
    x = "",
    title = "Figure 1: Predictors of Conflict Onset",
    caption = "Note: Coefficients and 95% confidence intervals."
  )
